author: Grimms
text: A great king of a land far away in the East had a daughter who was very beautiful, but so proud, and haughty, and conceited, that none of the princes who came to ask her in marriage was good enough for her, and she only made sport of them.

author: Grimms
text: Once upon a time the king held a great feast, and asked thither all her suitors; and they all sat in a row, ranged according to their rank --kings, and princes, and dukes, and earls, and counts, and barons, and knights.

author: Grimms
text: Then the princess came in, and as she passed by them she had something spiteful to say to every one.

author: Grimms
text: The first was too fat: "He"s as round as a tub," said she.

author: Grimms
text: The next was too tall: "What a maypole!" said she.

author: Grimms
text: The next was too short: "What a dumpling!" said she.

author: Grimms
text: The fourth was too pale, and she called him "Wallface."

author: Grimms
text: The fifth was too red, so she called him "Coxcomb."

author: Grimms
text: The sixth was not straight enough; so she said he was like a green stick, that had been laid to dry over a baker"s oven.

author: Grimms
text: And thus she had some joke to crack upon every one: but she laughed more than all at a good king who was there.

author: Grimms
text: "Look at him," said she; "his beard is like an old mop; he shall be called Grisly-beard."

author: Grimms
text: So the king got the nickname of Grisly-beard.

author: Grimms
text: But the old king was very angry when he saw how his daughter behaved, and how she ill-treated all his guests; and he vowed that, willing or unwilling, she should marry the first man, be he prince or beggar, that came to the door.

author: Grimms
text: Two days after there came by a travelling fiddler, who began to play under the window and beg alms; and when the king heard him, he said, "Let him come in."

author: Grimms
text: So they brought in a dirty-looking fellow; and when he had sung before the king and the princess, he begged a boon.

author: Grimms
text: Then the king said, "You have sung so well, that I will give you my daughter for your wife."

author: Grimms
text: The princess begged and prayed; but the king said, "I have sworn to give you to the first comer, and I will keep my word."

author: Grimms
text: So words and tears were of no avail; the parson was sent for, and she was married to the fiddler.

author: Grimms
text: When this was over the king said, "Now get ready to go--you must not stay here--you must travel on with your husband."

author: Grimms
text: Then the fiddler went his way, and took her with him, and they soon came to a great wood.

author: Grimms
text: "Pray," said she, "whose is this wood?"

author: Grimms
text: "It belongs to King Grisly-beard," answered he; "hadst thou taken him, all had been thine."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah! unlucky wretch that I am!" sighed she; "would that I had married King Grisly-beard!"

author: Grimms
text: Next they came to some fine meadows.

author: Grimms
text: "Whose are these beautiful green meadows?" said she.

author: Grimms
text: "They belong to King Grisly-beard, hadst thou taken him, they had all been thine."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah! unlucky wretch that I am!" said she; "would that I had married King Grisly-beard!"

author: Grimms
text: Then they came to a great city.

author: Grimms
text: "Whose is this noble city?" said she.

author: Grimms
text: "It belongs to King Grisly-beard; hadst thou taken him, it had all been thine."

author: Grimms
text: "Ah! wretch that I am!" sighed she; "why did I not marry King Grisly-beard?"

author: Grimms
text: "That is no business of mine," said the fiddler: "why should you wish for another husband?

author: Grimms
text: Am not I good enough for you?"

author: Grimms
text: At last they came to a small cottage.

author: Grimms
text: "What a paltry place!" said she; "to whom does that little dirty hole belong?"

author: Grimms
text: Then the fiddler said, "That is your and my house, where we are to live."

author: Grimms
text: "Where are your servants?" cried she.

author: Grimms
text: "What do we want with servants?" said he; "you must do for yourself whatever is to be done.

author: Grimms
text: Now make the fire, and put on water and cook my supper, for I am very tired."

author: Grimms
text: But the princess knew nothing of making fires and cooking, and the fiddler was forced to help her.

author: Grimms
text: When they had eaten a very scanty meal they went to bed; but the fiddler called her up very early in the morning to clean the house.

author: Grimms
text: Thus they lived for two days: and when they had eaten up all there was in the cottage, the man said, "Wife, we can"t go on thus, spending money and earning nothing.

author: Grimms
text: You must learn to weave baskets."

author: Grimms
text: Then he went out and cut willows, and brought them home, and she began to weave; but it made her fingers very sore.

author: Grimms
text: "I see this work won"t do," said he: "try and spin; perhaps you will do that better."

author: Grimms
text: So she sat down and tried to spin; but the threads cut her tender fingers till the blood ran.

author: Grimms
text: "See now," said the fiddler, "you are good for nothing; you can do no work: what a bargain I have got!

author: Grimms
text: However, I"ll try and set up a trade in pots and pans, and you shall stand in the market and sell them."

author: Grimms
text: "Alas!" sighed she, "if any of my father"s court should pass by and see me standing in the market, how they will laugh at me!"

author: Grimms
text: But her husband did not care for that, and said she must work, if she did not wish to die of hunger.

author: Grimms
text: At first the trade went well; for many people, seeing such a beautiful woman, went to buy her wares, and paid their money without thinking of taking away the goods.

author: Grimms
text: They lived on this as long as it lasted; and then her husband bought a fresh lot of ware, and she sat herself down with it in the corner of the market; but a drunken soldier soon came by, and rode his horse against her stall, and broke all her goods into a thousand pieces.

author: Grimms
text: Then she began to cry, and knew not what to do.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah! what will become of me?" said she; "what will my husband say?"

author: Grimms
text: So she ran home and told him all.

author: Grimms
text: "Who would have thought you would have been so silly," said he, "as to put an earthenware stall in the corner of the market, where everybody passes? but let us have no more crying; I see you are not fit for this sort of work, so I have been to the king"s palace, and asked if they did not want a kitchen-maid; and they say they will take you, and there you will have plenty to eat."

author: Grimms
text: Thus the princess became a kitchen-maid, and helped the cook to do all the dirtiest work; but she was allowed to carry home some of the meat that was left, and on this they lived.

author: Grimms
text: She had not been there long before she heard that the king"s eldest son was passing by, going to be married; and she went to one of the windows and looked out.

author: Grimms
text: Everything was ready, and all the pomp and brightness of the court was there.

author: Grimms
text: Then she bitterly grieved for the pride and folly which had brought her so low.

author: Grimms
text: And the servants gave her some of the rich meats, which she put into her basket to take home.

author: Grimms
text: All on a sudden, as she was going out, in came the king"s son in golden clothes; and when he saw a beautiful woman at the door, he took her by the hand, and said she should be his partner in the dance; but she trembled for fear, for she saw that it was King Grisly-beard, who was making sport of her.

author: Grimms
text: However, he kept fast hold, and led her in; and the cover of the basket came off, so that the meats in it fell about.

author: Grimms
text: Then everybody laughed and jeered at her; and she was so abashed, that she wished herself a thousand feet deep in the earth.

author: Grimms
text: She sprang to the door to run away; but on the steps King Grisly-beard overtook her, and brought her back and said, "Fear me not!

author: Grimms
text: I am the fiddler who has lived with you in the hut.

author: Grimms
text: I brought you there because I really loved you.

author: Grimms
text: I am also the soldier that overset your stall.

author: Grimms
text: I have done all this only to cure you of your silly pride, and to show you the folly of your ill-treatment of me.

author: Grimms
text: Now all is over: you have learnt wisdom, and it is time to hold our marriage feast."

author: Grimms
text: Then the chamberlains came and brought her the most beautiful robes; and her father and his whole court were there already, and welcomed her home on her marriage.

author: Grimms
text: Joy was in every face and every heart.

author: Grimms
text: The feast was grand; they danced and sang; all were merry; and I only wish that you and I had been of the party.
